course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Introduction to Western Literature
course.description: This course will introduce students to methods of reading western literary texts in English or in English translation. Its focus is on short stories, poems, and plays. Texts chosen will be those exploring aspects of initiation, romance and family, social and cultural issues in race, gender, and identity.

reviews.author: app_Sci
reviews.title: An Exhausting Course for Engineers. Take it only if you are good in literature.
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is actually pretty interesting.  However, the instructor do not send lecture notes to CANVAS, which means you are pretty lost if you do not attend many classes. She only gives her lecture notes in class. Thus, it is better to attend the classes as this course have PRS.
There are 3 major parts:
Short Stories (parts of stories, irony, symbol, theme,...)
Poem (literary devices, types of poems,...)
Drama (two examples are chosen: Oedipus the King and Trifles)
Midterm will be on Short Story, Final will be on Poem and Drama.
The course is fun without exams, exams are the real pain.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching is good. She interacts with students a lot and reaches out to you if she thinks you need help.
reviews.comment_grading:
Do note that D is pretty subjective comment due to what grade I got.
10% class participation by answering PRS
20% creative writing (Poem)
30% Midterm
40% Final
I got good marks in attendance, only missed one class.
Got decent marks in my poem. I believe my poem's mark is about average in the class.
Got below mean 2 SD in Midterm. the full mark is 90 and the mean is 60, SD 15
(How the hell did they do so well !!!!!!!!!!!)
Do not know how I did in finals (no marks given), but I think somewhere around below mean 2SD to below mean 1SD.
Got a C- at the end.
(USTSPACE is filled with lots of 學霸s who say course have a good grade. I am here to say the truth.)
The course itself is fun, but the exams are the real pain.
reviews.comment_workload:
Giving an E is my very subjective comment of this course's workload. A more objective comment would be a C.
Yes, you will only have to read the reading materials, and only write a short poem, but this is not the important part. The important part lies in the 70% in midterm and finals.
As someone who are not good with literature of any kind, I struggled to understand the more advanced part of this course.
Yes, I attended the classes and do know the definitions given by the teacher, but there are some more advanced stuff that needed more than class participation.
Think twice before enrolling in this course. If you are not good (or at least OK) with literature, then perhaps you should not enroll this course.

reviews.author: Frank
reviews.comment_content:
Narrative, Poetry and Drama are covered in class.

Mid-term is covers Narrative, while the Final covers both Poetry and Drama.

Oedipus the King and Trifles were the required reading for Drama. As for Narrative and Poetry, an extensive range was given.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Wong is very passionate about literature and chose a wide range of narratives and poems to analyse in class. She carefully guides students through the text ensuring that each line is understood. She encourages interaction in class for the sharing of different perspectives of the same text. Hence, participation is rewarded.

Professor Wong is also encourages students to ask questions whether in class, or through email/consultation, as she understands many students may not have any background in Literature.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment:
Class Participation 10%
Mid-term Exam 30%
Creative writing 20%    
Final Examination 40%

Creative Writing involves writing a poem according to one of the topics provided.

Exams are based on discussions in class. In-class attendance is recommended.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly readings to be covered in class. Apart from Drama, the readings are not too long. There are usually PRS questions in the lecture regarding the reading for attendance purposes.

The only major assignment is the creative writing and Professor Wong gives about a month for students to work on their poem before the deadline. She also provides examples of good poems from previous batches to give students a better idea of her grading. Through the different poems she covers in class, she teaches several literary techniques or devices which she expects to be used in students' creative writing. Thus, students need not worry too much about what is expected from the creative writing component.

reviews.author: shittygrades
reviews.title: IT'S A TRAP!!! 最憎偽grade神!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Three core parts: short stories, poems and drama. For short stories, 5 stories will be taught in class. You will learn to identify the themes and the literature devices used in every stories. This parts takes up to 50% of the course. However, it only appears in your mid-term exam.
After the mid-term, 4 sets(5-6 poems per set) of poems and 2 drama scripts will be covered. They will appear in your final exam. Creative writing on a poem is also assigned, which I will introduce later. Similarly, you will also learn to identify the themes and devices used in poems and drama scripts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not bad. You can see that she is well prepared for lectures and tries to make literature more interesting. I think she should upload all lecture notes to Canvas to allow online revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Class Participation: Complete the PRS during lectures
20% Creative Writing: Writing a poem on one of the four given topics, examples such as a response to a poem taught in class, as well as some topics from poems
30% Mid-term exam: The exam covers only on the part of short stories, containing MCQs and around 5 short questions.
40% Final Exam: Covers poems and drama scripts taught in class. Similar format as the mid-term.

My Grades:
Attendance: Missed 1 PRS after add-drop period
Creative Writing: A-
Midterm: 64/12x, Mean 60, S.D. 15
Final Exam: ? (average performance)
FINAL GRADE: B
完全唔滿意
reviews.comment_workload:
Before every lecture, you are expected to read the poem/reading she will cover, so that you can easily catch up with her.  The reading are not time-consuming. There's only one assignment, the creative writing. You are given two weeks time to complete it, which I think is pretty adequate.

佢成日講埋D "I don't think you should care too much about statistics" "I enjoy your work"既大話, 當我真係final below mean都好，佢講到自己好鐘意派grade咁，有份20% 既 A- assignment 點都拉個B+啦，食B真係...。見到review有人仲慘。佢喺到扮grade神引人落搭，然後最後一個grade kill你。建議大家唔好盡信A range 飛機post，除非你好彩，否則B就係盡頭。

reviews.author: supersherlockxd
reviews.title: Really an introductory course - don't expect anything more
reviews.comment_content:
Yes, I know it's been four years, but I find it a cautionary tale now that I am studying a legitimate language program -

This course requires students to read short stories, poetry, and drama. The literary period covered is wide (from ancient Greece to Shakespeare to modern literature). You'll get a taste of everything, which sacrifices the depth of analysis within each text. Also, the same texts are usually taught at the introductory or intermediate levels in language programs, meaning you'll get a taste of how literature-related courses are structured in language programs.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lisa always said literature is all about arguing your point, and there is no one definite answer in literature. However, there lacks argumentative writing in the whole course - while we were asked to share our opinions in class, most of the time the teaching would involve basic literary techniques and terminology. Personally, I found the course more restrictive that Lisa stated, especially when the assessment items were based on MCQ and short answers (which have definitive answers).

The reason I have to write this review after four years: currently, I'm studying a complete language program. Since I studied HUMA1300, my university has transferred the introductory literature course for me. The lack of essay writing proved to be problematic in the subsequent courses (one of which I am currently taking): I had little idea on how literary analysis should be done. I had to seek my professors' consultation to have a crash course on literary analysis, reading the course materials of the introductory course I was given the transfer.

I guess Lisa's perspective is applicable within her expertise (comparative literature), where her students are trained in academic writing. But don't expect this introductory course to be anything more, especially if you plan to further study literature courses (whether in HKUST or elsewhere).
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation (10%)
Quiz (30%) - MCQs, T/F, short questions. Basically, a MT.
Creative writing (20%) - a poem with three drafts, but Lisa seems to be leaning toward the more "traditional" form of poetry
Exam (40%) - again, MCQs, T/F, short questions

Eventually got an A-, but heard some people got F.
reviews.comment_workload: Only assignment was to complete the piece of creative writing. Reading depends on the exact lesson, but I'd say it's light reading for literature courses.

reviews.author: pipipipi
reviews.title: Interesting course with boring professor
reviews.comment_content:
Unit 1. Introduction
Byron, “Ode to Napoleon Buonaparte”, “Prometheus”
P.B. Shelley, Prometheus Unbound (Act 1)

Unit 2. Shadows of Revolution
Hugo, Victor. Ninety-Three. (Book III THE MASSACRE OF SAINT BARTHOLOMEW) 1
Conrad, Joseph. The Duel. (Chapter 2)

Unit 3. Utopia and Dystopia
Chernyshevsky, Nikolai. What Is to Be Done? (An Extraordinary Man)
Orwell, George. 1984: A Novel. (Chapter 1)

Unit 4. Trauma

Unit 5. Symbolism and Modernism Jean-Luc Godard, La Chinoise，1967
Bely, Andrey. Petersburg: A Novel in Eight Chapters.
(selected chapters)

Unit 6. Fourth Industrial Revolution

reviews.comment_teaching:
TL;DR: She put long paragraphs on her ppt slides and she just read it straight from her slides. Nice professor but still very very very boring.

The professor is soooooooooo boring as she would read straight from the PPT slides when she pasted almost an entire article on the slides (around 200 words PER SLIDE). And the slides were not uploaded on canvas so you had to pay close attention to what she READ. She also barely helped to analyse the content or literary devices, but spent most of the time explaining the background information of the book and the author. Although she was boring, she was very helpful and nice as she and the TA would help you if you ask them anything. She also tried to start discussions in class but not many students would speak up.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite fair. You will get good grade if you put enough effort in. But the professor was so boring that it made a supposedly fun course super boring and a complete waste of time.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload was low. There was no assignment and mid terms. You just had to read the assigned readings and there would be random ungraded PRS quizzes about facts in the readings to take attendance. But the project and final exam would require more work, though statistics of these two were not disclosed.

Assessment
Class Participation 5%
In-class quiz 25%
Final Group Presentation 35%
Final Examination 35%

reviews.author: vvs
reviews.title: Pretty good class if you like Western Lit
reviews.comment_content:
Like the course title suggests, an intro to Western Literature.
Nothing too heavy, most of the books we read like I, Robot were really easy to grasp and we never had to read the full novel, mostly just one chapter or around 30 pages per week.
She doesn't take attendance except for spontaneous pop quizzes.
reviews.comment_teaching: She is really sweet, as is her TA. She tries to make the class more interesting by showing lots of videos and giving us questions to discuss in class, however she sometimes just read from her ppt slides which are NOT available on Canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was fine.
She places a lot of emphasis on in-class participation and pop quizzes via IPRS on the latest reading assignment. You can use Google etc. during those pop quizzes (participation & quizzes are around 10% of the grade I believe).


Another important part is a final group presentation (35% of grade) in the final week of the semester, as well as a final exam, but there's no midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: Really low compared to other classes in my opinion, just speak up a few times over the course of the sem and make sure she remembers your face. Additionally, take notes or take photos of the slides as those are not uploaded on Canvas, but are necessary to understand some of the key aspects of the class you'll possibly be tested on.

reviews.author: Cath
reviews.title: Only take if you like reading and literature
reviews.comment_content:
It's a good course to learn literature, but the ones used are not the 'usual' ones (I expected something like Shakespeare or Paradise Lost but none of that). Also, notes are not posted on Canvas.

Always watch the assignment tab in Canvas.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor expects the class to be active, and the teaching is good. As said, none of these will be in Canvas, so ready your phone if you want the presentation (it doesn't help much, honestly, so...)
reviews.comment_grading:
5%      Class Participation
25%    In-class quiz
35%    Final Group presentation
35%    Final Examination

The final exam has essays, so prepare yourself.
Also, sometimes there are workshops you can join to help.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much. Assignments are reading parts of a book (never full novel), and sometimes to join workshops. You need to speak up at least 3 times, so I suggest you read the assignment.

reviews.author: Juliet Chung
reviews.comment_content:
It basically introduces 3 literary genres, including short story, poetry and drama. The instructor goes through one piece of literary work every lecture or every week to demonstrate the skill of literary work. However, the instructor will not post any analysis of the literary work on canvas. Students need to listen to the instructor analysis and jot notes by themselves. What the students jot down will be the content that can be revised for midterm and final. Sometimes, for some difficult terms or concepts, the instructor will post the slide of the related terms/ concepts on canvas to help students to understand.

Syllabus and Schedule

Week 1 (4 and 6 Sept.)

Fiction reading: Plot and Initiation Story
Ernst Hemingway, “The Killers”

Week 2 (11 and 13 Sept.)
Setting and Characterization

Week 3 (18 and 20 Sept.)

Week 6

Modernist Poetics

Weeks 10-11          (6-15 Nov.)   
Drama reading: Greek Culture and Tragedy
Sophocles, Oedipus the King (with film clips)

Week 13          (29 Nov.)
Review
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is very nice. She encourages discussion in class and tries to invite students for participation. Also, she explains most details of the texts as long as you can jot them down and it would be enough for midterm and final.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment

Class Participation                                                    10%
Mid-term Exam                                                         30%
Creative writing                                                         20%    
Final Examination                                                      40%

I attended all the lectures and took all the IPRS, got 83/90 for the midterm (mean:60) and a B+ for my creative writing. I don't know my final score but I got an A for the course.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty low. Just weekly reading before the class and one creative writing of a 200 words poem. The readings are not long and would not require lots of time (usually 10-20mins). Also, attendance would be given as long as IPRS was taken, no matter what answer(s) you chose.

The professor uses a few videos and such. She loves to facilitate discussions among the students, but if there aren't any active speakers in the class, then the whole class would be a bit awkward. She also teaches World Literature. The thing that may deter you away from this class would be that she reads directly off her PPT slides.

The teaching assistant is Song Han, a humanities Masters student studying Chinese Literature.


Syllabus:
Requirements:
You are expected to attend all classes and stay for the entire class. I measure class participation based on the following criteria: arriving to class on time, completing required reading (30 pages per week), engaging in class discussion, and respectfully listening when your classmates speak.
reviews.comment_grading:

25%    In-class quiz
35%    Final Group presentation
35%    Final Examination

The reading is relatively light, with only a few chapters. NO FULL NOVELS and etc. There will be discussion in class, so if you want to speak up, you should probably do the reading.

reviews.author: Jan_ccy
reviews.comment_content:
Simply introduce basic literature to students.
The content will be funny if u have never learned literature before.
The content simply covers poetry, short stories and plays.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the instructor is no bad, but as a literature professor, sometimes she could not pronounce some words correctly and I was shocked.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the mc questions in the exams are stupid because it simply just ask some detail parts about the text books. Also,there will be one assignment which is writing your own poem. If u have studied literature before, this is a weird but easy course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy. Just remember there will attendance taking. Also, one mid term, one final and one assignment. But I think the exam time is not long enough for answering the questions so u have to write quickly!

reviews.author: yys
reviews.title: Great course IF you love literature
reviews.comment_content:
Short stories, poetry and drama.

The texts were interesting and beautiful and touching etc. I am very happy to be introduced to these works of literature.

In general, you get a short story per week (3 to 4 pages) which you may read before the lecture. There were a few poems. Most texts would not be as challenging as Shakespearean works, but your English proficiency may still affect your understanding. There will be detailed explanation and discussion in the lectures.

The drama part will be mostly focused on Oedipus the King and Trifles. You are recommended to buy Oedipus the King, which is a cheap little book and a good read anyway.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good presentation and explanation of literary works and devices. She is a great teacher, encourages discussions and likes to get response from students. Enjoyable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment
Class Participation 10%
Mid-term Exam 30%
Creative writing 20%
Final Examination 40%

I think attendance counts for 5%, which is done by PRS, but your response is not graded.

Generous grading for the creative writing. You may draw inspirations from the course content, but I feel that you will do best if you pick a topic of interest to you. No need to cram difficult words in, just make it interesting and meaningful. I shared my opinion regarding a social issue, and got A-.

There were mc questions in exams, but the majority of the points were in long questions. The marking of individual questions were quite lax. That being said, you have to write more than a few words, elaborate and give examples. This is a literature course. Answering "I agree, period" to an open-ended question does not make any sense. People with HKDSE experience should have understood that.

You get a decent grade if you can understand the things taught in the course and appreciate literature, unlike HKDSE Chinese.

p.s. PLEASE GO TO THE LECTURES.
reviews.comment_workload:
Personally I did not do a lot. I went over the readings before lecture, and not a lot before the exams.

The creative writing part was a poem, you can write however long you like, mine was 4 quatrains. You can finish it within an hour before the deadline, but please don't.

For the exams, you should be familiar to the texts and think about the questions raised in the lectures. Taking notes during the lectures should help, but I did okay without.

利申: Overall A-

reviews.author: shreyars
reviews.comment_content: This course will introduce students to methods of reading western literary texts in English. The professor would cover 3 aspects of the Western Literature - short stories, poems and drama.  Texts chosen will be those exploring aspects of initiation, romance and family, social and cultural issues in race, gender, and identity. Since literature is a window on culture and humanity, the course aims to deepen students’ understanding of people from different cultures and the complexity of life.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ms. Lisa is a really sweet professor and has a great understanding for literature. She expects you to read the class material in advance and discusses the main things about the subject material in class.
She is also really helpful if you approach her in office hours.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation                                                      10%
Mid-term Exam                                                            30%
Creative writing (Poem)                                                20%    
Final Examination                                                        40%
reviews.comment_workload: There is almost no workload in the course except the creative writing part for which also the professor gives you a lot of time before the final submission.

reviews.author: Eamon Suen
reviews.title: A Superb Course For Beginners!
reviews.comment_content:
As previous reviews mentioned, the course is divided into three main parts: short stories, poetry and plays. Timing-wise, each component takes up around 1/3 of the time.

As the course title suggests, it teaches basic skills of literature such as identifying different literary devices, analyzing plot, style (short stories), usage of meter, rhyming, musicality (poetry), dialogue, soliloquy, setting, emotions, and so on (plays). Of course, this is merely part of the content and it is highly recommended for you to give this course a try first.

PS: Reading materials are great!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Perhaps it comes with experience, but the overall pace of the class is comfortable. The class lasts for an hour and 20 minutes, and I believe class discussions took up more than half of the time. Lisa is patient enough for everyone to speak their minds and discuss the content of the reading materials even though we don't always make sense.

It is quite the perfect class if you wish to learn about literature from scratch like me!
reviews.comment_grading:
There are four grading components: PRS (Attendance), Mid-Term Exam, Creative Writing Assignment (Write a poem) and a Final Exam.

PRS is simple. I am still unsure if you get the points if you got the answers wrong, but I think it's simply used to take attendance. Read the assigned materials thoroughly (should take 10 - 20 minutes for stories/plays, shorter for poems) and you'll get it right easy enough.

Mid-term exam* was tough. Basically, it tests on everything taught in the lectures before, which in my case only included short stories. There were questions on plot, message, settings - but they are not difficult, per se. But you have to answer 5 MCs + 5 LQs in one hour, so your time management must be spot on.

Creative Writing Assignment was fun. After learning about poems for a few lectures, you will have to start writing - your ultimate goal is to submit two drafts and a final product. Grading is quite chill (introductory course after all), so just enjoy the process.

Final exam*: Format is the same as Mid-Term Exam. However, only content covered after the Mid-term would be tested, so you will have to know your poems and plays. Questions are rather simple, and you are given more than double the time of the Mid-Term, so study and you'll be rewarded.

*Grading for exams are chill. Just make sure you state your key points and explain in two - three sentences. Don't overwrite!
reviews.comment_workload: Main points are covered in "Grading". But overall, there is only one assignment in the whole semester and the reading materials are light enough that you could usually finish them within 10 - 20 minutes.

reviews.author: graceltw
reviews.comment_content:
Short story, Poetry and Drama

Covered basic literature concepts such that students with no literature background can easily understand the concepts. Some Greek drama terms might be a bit hard to understand at first, but if you are genuinely interested in the content you will not find them too difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor likes interacting with students and please answer the question she has raised! She will remember those who has participated actively in class, which is also good for your participation score too (Plus, there is no right or wrong in literature and everyone can have their own interpretation, so only by discussion can you really understand the fun part of literature)
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty easy for me - If you pay attention in class and understand the themes of each text and key takeaways the professor highlighted (she has one or two focus for each texts taught), you would be able to ace the course without putting to much effort in studying.

There are MC questions in both mid-term and finals, which I don't think is appropriate for a literature course (I have talked to professor about this but then she said many HKUST students have complained previously about not having 'standardized' answers and marking schemes for exams, which is just pathetic). Write more in the exams to show your knowledge of the texts - I saw many students left the exam venue after like 30 minutes which I don't think anyone can write that fast enough to cover all key points.
reviews.comment_workload:
Normal - you just have to read the texts before class which takes you less than 30 minutes I guess).

One creative writing (poem with two drafts) - might take up slightly more time but I finished the whole poem in a night so I guess it is still quite light compared to other courses.

One mid-term and one final - MCs and short questions.

PRS question each lecture for taking attendance.

reviews.author: hellokitty
reviews.comment_content: Course is split into 3 main parts: Short Stories, Plays and Poems. Course is pretty similar to IB English Literature in that you will be analysing the Stories etc. The types of stories, plays and poems vary a lot an touch upon several different themes such as race, gender, societal norms and identity. The course can be very interesting if you have an aptitude and appreciation for English Literature
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lisa Wong was a pretty good professor overall. She was very open to answering questions during class as well as after class, and very flexible with making appointments to see her. To get the best of the class, it's better to be engaged and ask/ answer her questions rather than being quiet the whole time. She tends to remember names of those who are more active in class.

One thing I didn't like was that she didn't upload her powerpoints onto canvas which can be annoying. If you can't get all the notes written down during class, you're pretty much out of luck unless someone else wrote it down. Lots of things discussed during classes are on the exams and not all of it is covered in the notes she gives
reviews.comment_grading: The mean was pretty low for the midterms due to tricky multiple choice questions and insufficient notes given by the prof. If however you have taken a lot of notes during class, it should be ok.
reviews.comment_workload:
A fair amount of reading to be done every week. The pace is quiet fast. If you don't get the reading done, it can be quiet hard to understand what's going on in the class and you will most likely be unable to make a contribution to class discussions.

One of the assignments was to write a poem- highly subjective on whether or not you think it is a lot of work

Exams were mostly MCQ for the midterms and Mostly Long essay questions for the final.

reviews.author: Galen
reviews.comment_content:
From the syllabus:

This course will introduce students to methods of reading western literary texts in English. Its focus is on short stories, poems, and plays. Students will learn to analyze the artistic and imaginative use of language, and develop the ability to think creatively and critically. Texts chosen will be those exploring aspects of initiation, romance and family, social and cultural issues in race, gender, and identity. Since literature is a window on culture, the course aims to deepen students’ understanding of people from other cultures and the complexity of life.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Lisa is very helpful and tries her best to answer your questions. She is very knowledgable in the area of Literature and tries her best to make the class fun.

The only thing about this course is that she doesn't upload powerpoint slides on Canvas/LMES. So I had to jot notes down to make sure I didn't miss anything. E.g., If you skip classes, you might have the possibility that you might miss something important for the midterm.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation - 10%
Quiz - 30%
Creative writing - 20%
Examination - 40%

If you're an international student who did IB. Make sure you clarify the format of your answers with the prof or the TA. (*This course has a particular style of answer you have to write) Just don't expect the essay questions to be written in a IB Lang&Lit course format!
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload was fine, roughly the same level of a IB Language & Literate Course.

For this particular semester, we had to write a 1 short poem which had a significant weighting and read Odepus for the final exam.

In total, there was 1 creative writing assignment, 1 Midterm + 1 Final Exam.

Exams had a combination of MCQ and Long questions.

reviews.author: Anita
reviews.title: Interesting with reasonable workload and grading
reviews.comment_content:
3 main parts in the course:
short stories - various topics including romance and detective etc.
poems
drama
reviews.comment_teaching:
Helpful and knowledgeable professor, feel free to ask questions after class.

No powerpoint slides on lmes, have to jot notes (and occasionally take photos) in class.

Reminder: sit in the front of classroom, professor often uses the whiteboard for teaching and you won't be able to see if you sit after the 8th row

Always have in-class discussion, no cold calling though
reviews.comment_grading:
Reasonable grade
Prof will tell how many marks you need to get into A range in the beginning of semester (80% for A range in my case)

In-class questions for attendance taking (and as quizzes)

Remember what prof has repeated and emphasized in class as they will very likely appear in exams, if you can regurgitate what she has said then basically you will get an A for sure (not much stuff to memorize compared to SBM major courses)
reviews.comment_workload:
About 1 short story / poem / short play every lesson, a long drama at the end of semester.
1 creative writing (poem in my case) + 1 midterm + 1 final
MC + long questions for exams

reviews.author: Genie
reviews.comment_content: Touched briefly on various western literature genres such as Short Stories, Drama Scripts and Poems. If you love reading, this course is perfect for you. Different literary terms and ways of literature appreciation are taught.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lisa is very dedicated to her teaching and she welcomes all kinds of questions. She tries to remember the names of her students and invite them to participate actively in class. Her teaching is well-delivered and easy to understand.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very good. I got an A for my creative writing (which is a poem) and around 80% in both exams. Overall, I got A-.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much except a few readings and the creative writing assignment. Going to lectures is highly encouraged. They are very useful and Lisa uses iPRS to take attendance in class.

reviews.author: Tiffany W
reviews.comment_content:
Short stories, drama (plays) and poetry
This semester's play (there were about 2-3 plays, the main focus was on Oedipus, a Greek tragedy). Students are strongly recommended to buy the book (or have the latest copy) so that they can have a general idea of the content for the finals.
reviews.comment_teaching: Reading more of the reading materials beforehand will help in understanding lectures, attendance is taken through PRS while the questions will be mainly about the text the class will be discussing for that lecture.

Reading materials are usually 1-2 pages, light workload (not much assignments)
Midterm and finals are non cumulative
